{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3145577,"name":"Nathan Manhardt","username":"Xolverr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/xolverr/{size}/211198_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-14T23:53:41.441Z","cooked":"

My subteam and I were wondering if there is something we could write to have our robot automatically tune our PID controllers. This kind of thing will be very helpful if we can get it working; our team’s testing period is limited and that time would be better spent on other things. We’ve tried a few things out and researched but haven’t been able to find much. Personally I have very limited experience with PID, and the tuning process can be quite tedious and time-consuming. We are using Java, CANCoders for input, and NEO motors (SwerveDriveSpecialties MK4 Swerve Modules). Anyone have any ideas?

While I have this post open, might as well ask about this too. We’ve been having issues for a while now with our CANCoders’ absolute positions shifting. This is going to become more of an issue very soon once our robot’s arm is mounted.

Maybe you can look into feedforward control loops? Essentialy does the same thing that PID does by generating constants via a dataset.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-02-15T00:13:41.575Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":346,"readers_count":345,"score":114.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":426844,"topic_slug":"automatic-pid-tuning","display_username":"Berke Sinan Yetkin","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/controllers/feedforward.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Feedforward Control in WPILib — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":78}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48509,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Software"},"post_url":"/t/automatic-pid-tuning/426844/2","custom_user_title":"Software","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"question","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3145593,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-15T00:28:51.603Z","cooked":"
Xolverr:

automatically tune

I’ve had success with a program called “AutoTune” that I found in an Arduino library and fixed the bugs and got it to work for our FRC motors. It takes about 1/4 second to tune a PID controller. My source code is in a couple of places in GitHub as are many other older versions from others.

BUT it’s not for the uninitiated. Understand PID first. AND Hand tuning is usually rated as superior to the autotune relay method. The WPILib documentation shows how to tune - it’s pretty clearly stated and easy. Similarly CTRE documentation is an excellent resource. I think the Rev Client can help as the CTRE Phoenix Tuner does. Use these resources - that’s what my team does now.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-02-15T00:28:51.603Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":29,"reads":333,"readers_count":332,"score":226.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":426844,"topic_slug":"automatic-pid-tuning","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/automatic-pid-tuning/426844/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3145845,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-15T14:29:04.235Z","cooked":"

Introduction to System Identification — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation - System Identification is the general academic term for this kind of software.

The way I’d break it down:

First, picking good PID constants requires you either know enough about your hardware (IE, have an accurate-enough mathematical model of it) to guess correctly, or you just guess-and-check on the real hardware until it works.

Secondly, if you’re on real hardware, the guess-and-check or data collection can be automated - that’s the “auto tune” portion.

Critically though, for auto-tune to make sense, you still have to either know enough about the hardware, or have access to it. If the fundamental problem is “no access to real hardware”, just implementing auto-tuning won’t necessarily solve that problem.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-02-15T14:29:04.235Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":288,"readers_count":287,"score":107.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":426844,"topic_slug":"automatic-pid-tuning","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/pathplanning/system-identification/introduction.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Introduction to System Identification — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":36}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/automatic-pid-tuning/426844/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3145874,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-15T15:08:04.713Z","cooked":"
Xolverr:

CANCoders’ absolute positions shifting

I think the only way this can happen is if you have mechanical parts moving that aren’t supposed to be moving - usually the magnet since that’s the least obvious to observe.

Draw a line across the mechanism that should not be moving including drawing on the magnet with a Sharpie. If you see the absolute position shift, see if the drawn line segments no longer line up.

Our magents were hard to press in. With the tiniest bit of glue (hardly any or you won’t be able to press the magnet in all the way) the magnets are almost impossible to get out (there are CD posts about removal).

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-02-15T15:08:04.713Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":13,"reads":246,"readers_count":245,"score":119.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":426844,"topic_slug":"automatic-pid-tuning","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/automatic-pid-tuning/426844/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3145884,"name":"Nathan Manhardt","username":"Xolverr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/xolverr/{size}/211198_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-15T15:19:33.442Z","cooked":"

No that’s not the problem. Just having to constantly be focused on tuning it instead of being able to work on other things while it’s doing it’s thing.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-02-15T15:19:33.442Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":222,"readers_count":221,"score":99.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":426844,"topic_slug":"automatic-pid-tuning","display_username":"Nathan Manhardt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":24617,"username":"gerthworm","name":"Chris Gerth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57183,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3229 Software Captain"},"post_url":"/t/automatic-pid-tuning/426844/6","custom_user_title":"3229 Software Captain","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3145935,"name":"Jaccob Lee","username":"BresisBrosis","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bresisbrosis/{size}/200558_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-15T16:33:05.862Z","cooked":"

From the same team- We’ve loctited all 4 of the encoder magnets in place and most of them were nearly impossible to get out beforehand. We are going to check them again later today, but are you aware of anything else that might be causing this issue?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-02-15T16:33:05.862Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":16,"reads":187,"readers_count":186,"score":122.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":426844,"topic_slug":"automatic-pid-tuning","display_username":"Jaccob Lee","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":24594,"username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54551,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3229A - 3349A/M"},"post_url":"/t/automatic-pid-tuning/426844/7","custom_user_title":"3229A - 3349A/M","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3145939,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-15T16:35:39.213Z","cooked":"

The only way to skip the process of tuning against or characterizing a physical robot is to estimate the control gains theoretically. ReCalc can give you good theoretical estimates for most control gains provided you have good specifications of the dimensions of your mechanism.

As always with model-derived control gains, make sure you’re absolutely scrupulous about your units of measure or the thing won’t work.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-02-15T16:36:47.920Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":175,"readers_count":174,"score":55.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":426844,"topic_slug":"automatic-pid-tuning","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"http://reca.lc","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"ReCalc","clicks":48}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57183,"username":"Xolverr","name":"Nathan Manhardt","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/xolverr/{size}/211198_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/automatic-pid-tuning/426844/8","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3146112,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-15T19:06:58.901Z","cooked":"

A best practice is to put the absolute magnet positions into the java code so they can’t change by any external means. You didn’t indicate that there is any reason to believe that will help in this case but it’s something good to do.

If you describe your situation completely maybe I or others would think of something.

One thing another team did was over-spin their encoder. The CANcoder can go 15000 RPM but I have to ask!?

You do have them connected to 12V?

Which CANcoders are changing? Drive or turn motors? The arm?

How much are they changing?

When do they change? How soon after power on? What is the robot doing?

How do you know the values are changing? What are the indications or symptoms?
Are the lights green or is a magnet nearing out of range from the sensor?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-02-15T19:08:34.664Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":152,"readers_count":151,"score":40.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":426844,"topic_slug":"automatic-pid-tuning","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":54551,"username":"BresisBrosis","name":"Jaccob Lee","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bresisbrosis/{size}/200558_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/automatic-pid-tuning/426844/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3146136,"name":"Nathan Manhardt","username":"Xolverr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/xolverr/{size}/211198_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-15T19:26:18.123Z","cooked":"

A best practice is to put the absolute magnet positions into the java code so they can’t change by any external means. You didn’t indicate that there is any reason to believe that will help in this case but it’s something good to do.

If you describe your situation completely maybe I or others would think of something.

One thing another team did was over-spin their encoder. The CANcoder can go 15000 RPM but I have to ask!?

    Nope lol.

You do have them connected to 12V?

    Yes

Which CANcoders are changing? Drive or turn motors? The arm?

    Turn motors. The drive motors don’t have CANCoders.

How much are they changing?

    ± ~5°

When do they change?

    After we drive around for like 30-60 secs.

How soon after power on?

    ^^^

What is the robot doing?

    Driving

How do you know the values are changing?

    We have the abs values on SmartDashboard

What are the indications or symptoms?

    They change…

Are the lights green or is a magnet nearing out of range from the sensor?

    The lights are green (blinking fast). No magnets nearby. (Except for the motors of course)

We do have the offsets stored in the code and they are configured when the robots is turned on.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-02-15T19:27:58.382Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":125,"readers_count":124,"score":70.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":426844,"topic_slug":"automatic-pid-tuning","display_username":"Nathan Manhardt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":24594,"username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57183,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3229 Software Captain"},"post_url":"/t/automatic-pid-tuning/426844/10","custom_user_title":"3229 Software Captain","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3146143,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-15T19:31:12.356Z","cooked":"

If one CANcoder absolute calibration is off a few degrees, the robot will drift dramatically when you try to go straight. Is the robot driving wrong after the absolute orientation changes? (Usually this is a poor calibration noticed the instant you first try to drive straight.)

Why would you have even thought to display the magnet absolute orientation? I can’t imagine ever being interested in that except we print the configuration once at robotInit.

The robot does drive straight when we start. We did that to see why the robot wouldn’t drive striaght after a while.

You could try plotting a time series graph of the value to see if it drifts slowly or jumps in a single event.

Do we resort to looking at code to see if there is something there such as you are setting the magnet orientation every 20ms instead of once at the beginning?

Is your CAN bus terminated properly? Is the loading of the bus not too high?

I (a non-programmer) have a hard time understanding why all PID isn’t auto-tuning, at least on encoders and gyros.

You should be able to tell a system what you want it to do and what sensors you’re using, follow some prompts (like, say, turning a drive train/pivoting a joint/lifting an elevator manually to give the sensors maximum/minimum values), do it again approximately under joystick control to get an idea of necessary voltages for the system at hand, and then tell it to optimize the motion.

It uses PID math to come up with best guesses on initial kp, ki, and kd, then executes a first trial on command, reads what happened (because it should be able to log and see what happened), and then (if desired) makes adjustments on accuracy and speed until the client is satisfied or the software can’t optimize further. Common issues like stalling or oscillation around the set point are things that software should be able to identify and modify k values to deal with, aren’t they?

This seems like it should be a thing. I want this to be a thing, for our team and every team without a strong programming base. I’m probably completely insane.

Are you familiar with SysId?

The only difference between that and what you describe is that SysId has a particular set of driving signals that have been picked particularly to make sure that the best-fit problem is mathematically solvable, rather than letting you use a joystick.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2023-02-15T20:26:35.832Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":83,"readers_count":82,"score":26.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":426844,"topic_slug":"automatic-pid-tuning","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7547,"username":"pfreivald","name":"Patrick Freivald","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pfreivald/{size}/177405_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/automatic-pid-tuning/426844/15","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3146204,"name":"Trent Berrien","username":"Trent","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/trent/{size}/128680_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-15T20:33:43.774Z","cooked":"

The problem is that there is no objectively “correct” tunning. PID tuning in a way is an art form. Is overshoot ok? How long can you wait for the controller to settle? What is acceptable steady state error? What range of disturbances are you able to accept? There are many variations of the parameters that could also give you similar results. This is not to say that “auto tunning” is impossible or doesn’t exist, but often it’s more effort than tunning it manually with the right procedure.

Right, but you should be able to specify things like an acceptable range (including or not including overshoot), whether accuracy is more important that speed or vice-versa, etc.

And for a lot of us, I doubt we care in the slightest which variations of the parameters end up in the code as long as we get acceptable results.
